action.action-desc: Ms. Schrier (for herself and Mr. Meijer) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow parents pursuing a higher education degree to take the tax credit for expenses for household and dependent care services.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Tax Credit for Student Parents Act.

section.header: Part-time students allowed to take credit for expenses for household and dependent care services

subsection.text: Section 21 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended—

paragraph.text: in the heading, by inserting or education after gainful employment,
by striking employment-related expenses each place it appears and inserting employment- and education-related expenses, and

subparagraph.text: in the heading, by striking employment-related expenses and inserting employment- and education-related expenses, and
in subparagraph (A), by striking gainfully employed and inserting gainfully employed or a student.

paragraph.text: Section 21(e)(7) of such Code is amended to read as follows:

The term student means an individual who during each of 5 calendar months during the taxable year is carrying at least ½ the normal full-time work load for the course of study such individual is pursuing at an educational organization.

paragraph.header: Special rule for students and individuals incapable of caring for themselves
paragraph.text: Section 21(d)(2) of such Code is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.header: Special rule for students and individuals incapable of caring for themselves
paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), if a spouse is a student or a qualifying individual described in subsection (b)(1)(C), or if an unmarried individual is a student, such spouse or unmarried individual shall be deemed for each month during which such spouse or unmarried individual satisfies the ½-time requirement of subsection (e)(7), or during which such spouse is such a qualifying individual, to be gainfully employed and to have earned income of not less than—

subparagraph.text: $250 if subparagraph (c)(1) applies for the taxable year, or
$500 if subparagraph (c)(2) applies for the taxable year.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2022.
